questions.text: All the following statements regarding first-order kinetics are true except?

choices.text: Rate of elimination is proportional to plasma conc
Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

questions.solution:
In first order kinetics, constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time.

Difference Between First and Zero Order Kinetics

First Order Kinetics (Flow limited elimination) Zero Order Kinetics (Capacity limited elimination)
The rate of elimination is directly proportional to the drug concentration in the plasma The rate of elimination remains constant irrespective of drug concentration in the plasma
Clearance remains constant Clearance decreases with increase in plasma concentration of the drug
A constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in unit time. A constant amount of the drug is eliminated in unit time.
t½ remains constant t½ increases with dose

Ethanol follows zero-order kinetics. Drugs such as warfarin, phenytoin, theophylline, and tolbutamide also follow zero-order kinetics.

questions.text: Most adults treated with 4-5g/day of aspirin are in a state of:
questions.solution:
Most adults treated with 4–5 g/day of aspirin stay in a state of compensated respiratory alkalosis.

Aspirin and Acid-Base Balance

  • Usual analgesic doses (0.3–1.0 g) have practically no effect.
  • At anti-inflammatory doses(4-5g/d), respiratory stimulation predominates and tends to wash out CO2 despite increased production, causing respiratory alkalosis, which is compensated by increased renal excretion of HCO3¯.
  • An anion-gap metabolic acidosis then follows, due primarily to the accumulation of organic acids, including lactic acid and ketoacids.
  • The net effect of these changes is that most adults have either a primary respiratory alkalosis or, more commonly, a mixed primary respiratory alkalosis-primary metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for tularemia?
questions.solution:
Streptomycin is the drug of choice for tularemia, a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis (aerobic gram-negative bacteria).

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside. It may be administered by deep intramuscular injection or intravenously. Its uses include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Plague: rapid cure in 7–12 days
  • Tularemia: tetracyclines are the alternative drugs, especially in milder cases

Aminoglycosides are used to treat infections caused by aerobic gram-negative bacteria. These are bactericidal drugs and show rapid concentration-dependent killing. The inhibitory effect persists even after the serum concentration has fallen below the minimum inhibitory concentration (postantibiotic effect). High-dose, extended-interval dosing is hence effective. They inhibit protein synthesis by acting on multiple sites on the 30s and 50s ribosomal subunits. 

Aminoglycosides need therapeutic dose monitoring because of their narrow therapeutic index. These drugs are nephrotoxic and ototoxic. The dose has to be reduced in patients with impaired renal function. 

The uses of various aminoglycoside drugs are as follows:

  • Gentamicin is used for Pseudomonas infection (in combination with 3rd generation cephalosporin) and urinary tract infection
  • Streptomycin is used as a 2nd line agent for tuberculosis and amikacin for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis 
  • Oral neomycin is used for bowel preparation before surgery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve (DRC)?

choices.text: Drug D is the least potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug  B is the least potent

questions.solution:
The greater the shift of the curve towards the left, the more potent the drug is. Hence, drug D is the least potent.

Potency: It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. The greater the shift of the curve towards the left side, the higher is potency of the drug. This is because the desired response is being achieved at a lower drug dose.

Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B is the most potent, and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy: It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C, and D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: The anti-cancer drug that can cross blood-brain barrier is ______.
questions.solution:
Lomustine can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Lomustine belongs to a class of nitrosoureas anti-cancer drugs. They are highly lipophilic and can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Anti-cancer drugs that can cross the blood-brain barrier:

  • Nitrosoureas: Lomustine, carmustine, semustine
  • Procarbazine
  • Temozolomide

Nitrosoureas cause interstrand DNA cross-linking, which is responsible for the cytotoxicity of the tumor. The use of nitrosoureas is presently limited to brain tumors due to their lipophilicity. They are effective in meningeal leukemia and brain tumors.

Side effects of nitrosoureas include profound and delayed myelosuppression. They are also highly carcinogenic and mutagenic. 

Apart from this, streptozocin is another nitrosourea compound that has a high affinity for islets of Langerhans.

questions.text: Gray baby syndrome is caused due to intake of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Gray baby syndrome occurs when high doses of chloramphenicol (100 mg/kg) were given prophylactically to neonates, especially premature babies.

This syndrome usually begins 2 to 9 days after starting the treatment. Initially in the first 24 hours, the baby develops vomiting, refusal to feed, irregular and rapid respiration, abdominal distention, periods of cyanosis, and passage of loose green stools. Over the next day, neonates turn to ashen-gray color and become hypothermic and flaccid.

It happens due to the developmental deficiency of the enzyme glucoronyl transferase. This enzyme metabolizes chloramphenicol in neonates. Its deficiency leads to an inability to excrete unconjugated drugs adequately through renal excretion.

Death occurs in 40% of patients within 2 days of initial symptoms, but if there is a recovery, there are no sequelae usually.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diabetic patient was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. He was started on digoxin. What will be the therapeutic plasma concentration of this drug?
questions.solution:
The therapeutic plasma concentration of digoxin is 0.5-1.4 ng/ml.

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside with a narrow therapeutic index and is used in the management of heart failure. It inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the myocardium leading to increased accumulation of intracellular sodium. Increased intracellular sodium prevents the efflux of calcium ions. This results in increased intracellular calcium which increases the contractility of the muscle.

Pharmacokinetics of digoxin:

Oral absorption 60–80%
Plasma t½ 40 hr
Therapeutic conc. 0.5–1.4 ng/ml
Toxic conc. > 2 ng/ml
Daily maintenance dose 0.125–0.5 mg
Route of elimination   Renal excretion
Route of administration Oral, IV

Clinical features of digoxin toxicity:

  • CNS manifestations - Drowsiness, neuralgia, headache, confusion, or giddiness
  • Ophthalmic manifestations - Visual aberration is an early indication of digitalis toxicity. Yellow-green distortion is the most common. Yellow halos around lights (xanthopsia) are seen. Visual acuity is reduced.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations- Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea, abdominal pain.
  • Cardiac manifestations - Palpitations, dyspnea, syncope, hypotension. The most serious side effect of digoxin is arrhythmia. They can present as extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.

Digoxin should be discontinued whenever toxicity is suspected. An effective antidote for digoxin toxicity is digibind, which is an anti-digoxin antibody. Arrhythmias should be treated.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with suicidal overdose of a drug. Patient is flabby and comatose with shallow failing respiration. BP is 80/40 mmHg and the lesion on the right knee is as shown. The likely poisoning is:
questions.solution:
The figure shows characteristic barbiturate blisters. This is a case of phenobarbitone poisoning.

 Acute Barbiturate poisoning:

Manifestations are due to excessive CNS depression—

  • Patient is flabby and comatose with shallow and failing respiration
  • Fall in BP and cardiovascular collapse
  • Renal shut down
  • Pulmonary complications
  • Bullous eruptions

Lethal dose depends on lipid solubility.

  • It is 2–3 g for the more lipid-soluble agents (short-acting barbiturates)
  • 5–10 g for less lipid-soluble phenobarbitone

Treatment

  • Gastric lavage
  • Supportive measures: such as, patent airway, assisted respiration, oxygen, maintenance of blood volume by fluid infusion and use of vasopressors—dopamine may be preferred for its renal vasodilating action.
  • Alkaline diuresis: with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
  • Haemodialysis and hemoperfusion

 

 

NOTE: There is no specific antidote for barbiturates.

questions.text: In diabetes insipidus, diuretic showing paradoxical anti-diuretic activity is:
questions.solution:
• Diuretic thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in diabetes insipidus.
  • Thiazides reduce urine volume in both pituitary origin as well as renal DI.

questions.text: Coronary steal phenomenon is caused by which of the following drugs:
questions.solution:
• Dipyridamole causes coronary steal phenomenon.
  • It is a powerful coronary dilator increases total coronary flow by preventing uptake and degradation of adenosine which is a local mediator involved in autoregulation of coronary flow in response to ischaemia.
  • By dilating resistance vessels in the non-ischaemic zone as well, it diverts the already reduced blood flow away from the ischaemic zone causing coronary steal phenomenon.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs may cause thyroid dysfunction:
questions.solution:
• Amiodarone interferes with thyroid function in many ways including inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and interaction with thyroid hormone receptor.
  • Goitre, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism may develop on chronic use.

AMIODARONE

  • Class III anti-arrhythmic
  • Resistant VT and recurrent VF are the most important indications for amiodarone
  • It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed

Adverse effects of amiodarone:

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on IV injection and after drug cumulation
  • Photosensitization
  • Corneal microdeposits 
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Goitre, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism

questions.text: Which of the following is true about orphan drugs?

choices.text: They are expired drugs which are no longer used in the market and are subsequently withdrawn.
They drugs are commonly used drugs but the cost is very high.
They are drugs for rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
They are drugs that are not used anymore.

questions.solution:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.

Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for the pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

Few examples of orphan drugs:

  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Digoxin antibody
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: Which of the following is a bradykinin receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist. It is approved for the use of hereditary angioedema. Icatibant reduces the hypotensive action of captopril indicating the role of inhibition of bradykinin breakdown in hypotensive action of captopril.

Rimonabant is a cannabinoid receptor antagonist that was used in obesity but withdrwan due to serious psychiatric adverse effects (Option A).

Moexipril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (Option C).

Eprosartan is an antiotensin receptor blocker (Option D).

questions.text: Potassium binder used in cases of hyperkalemia is
questions.solution:
Patiromer is a non-absorbed, cation exchange polymer that contains a calcium-sorbitol
counterion.

It increases fecal potassium excretion through binding of potassium in the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.

Binding of potassium reduces the concentration of free potassium in the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in a reduction of serum potassium levels.

Recent update: The FDA has approved Lokelma (sodium zirconium cyclosilicate), for the treatment of adults with hyperkalaemia in 2018. It is an insoluble, non-absorbed sodium zirconium silicate, formulated as a powder for oral suspension, that acts as a highly-selective potassium-removing agent.

questions.text: A patient with hypercholesterolemia on statin therapy presents to your OPD for follow-up. You notice his cholesterol is still high and decide to add on another drug that directly inhibits the absorption of cholesterol. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ezetimibe is the drug that prevents hypercholesterolemia by directly inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol.

Ezetimibe acts by interfering with a specific cholesterol transport protein NPC1L1 in the intestinal mucosa and reduces the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. It causes a compensatory increase in hepatic cholesterol synthesis but LDL cholesterol is decreased. Statins block this enhanced cholesterol synthesis (cholesterol synthesis inhibitors) and so their combination has a synergistic effect.

Option B: Orlistat is an anti-obesity drug that acts by inhibiting pancreatic and gastric lipase and thus interferes with the digestion and absorption of dietary triglycerides.

Option C: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant. The bile-acid sequestrants are highly positively charged and bind negatively charged bile acids. Because of their large size, the resins are not absorbed, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool.

Cholestyramine primarily reduces LDL levels by increasing hepatic bile acid synthesis; which results in increased LDL uptake and diversion of cholesterol to bile acid production. 

Option D: Niacin reduces lipolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and reduces hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

questions.text: A patient with ruptured spleen is taken for laparotomy. His blood pressure is 80/50 and heart rate is 125/min. Induction agent of choice for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Induction doses of ketamine increase blood pressure, heart rate and cardiac output that make it useful for anesthetizing patients at risk for hypotension.

In the present case, the patient is presenting with low blood pressure, the most appropriate agent would be ketamine.

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is caused by:
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia is caused by prilocaine.

It is due to the metabolism of the aromatic ring of prilocaine to o-toluidine which is an oxidizing agent and oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia risk is directly associated with the total dose administered, usually appearing when doses exceed 8 mg/kg.

Intravenous administration of methylene blue is the treatment for methemoglobinemia.

Benzocaine can also cause methemoglobinemia similar to prilocaine.

questions.text: Bambuterol is a prodrug of _____
questions.solution:
Bambuterol is an ester prodrug of terbutaline. It is slowly hydrolysed by pseudocholinesterase in lungs and plasma to form active terbutaline.

It is administered orally and indicated in chronic and nocturnal asthma.

questions.text: A patient who was started on treatment for glaucoma comes to the casualty with acute onset breathlessness. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze is heard. Which of the following drugs might have led to this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchial asthma which was most likely precipitated by timolol.

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation. It precipitates bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals by beta-2 blockade.

Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF-2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma. 

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.
